awd_titl_txt: Investigating the connectivity of microbial food webs using thermodynamic models, stable isotope probing and genomics
awd_abstract_narration:
The habitability of Earth is maintained in part by the actions of microscopic organisms that continuously breakdown dead organic material and recycle the chemical elements needed by all living organisms. The Earth's microbiome, as it is also known as, consists of bacteria and archaea as well as protists and viruses that prey upon them. The complex and dynamic milieu of interacting microscopic organisms can be difficult to disentangle and understand because as many as a billion bacteria and archaea, and 10 billion viruses, can be found in a liter of water or a gram of soil. Recent advances in molecular biology are beginning to allow scientists to determine which microscopic organisms are present in an environmental sample, as well as how population numbers change over time and what the organisms are doing, such as consuming carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.  To understand and predict how microbial communities respond to environmental changes, or how they can be used in biotechnology, energy production or remediation of pollution, scientists construct mathematical models. Properly representing all the microbial interactions in extremely diverse microscopic worlds in a mathematical model is a great challenge. Researchers for this project have developed a novel modeling approach, which exploits a theory that argues complex systems - ones that can be assembled in many different ways - will likely arrange and organize themselves to maximize their consumption of usable energy, such as found in food or sunlight.  The theory, known as maximum entropy production (MEP), also predicts how microscopic communities should be structured; that is, who eats whom. To test the theory, researchers will use laboratory microcosms combined with molecular biological techniques to determine the structure of natural microbial communities and compare them to predictions made by the model.  The project also will support one postdoctoral researcher, and provide research training for 2 to 5 undergraduate students each year.

Preliminary modeling results based on the MEP theory show that microbial food webs constructed of strong predator-prey chains are effective at utilizing resources and dissipating free energy, while highly connected generalist food webs prevent effective use of resources and do not locate MEP solutions. The hypothesis that microbial communities organize to form strongly coupled predator-prey chains that are weakly interconnected will be tested with laboratory chemostats inoculated with natural microbial communities. Food web structure will be assessed with stable isotope probing techniques and the active consumers and their predators identified by sequencing of the labeled community. The results from the experiments will not only facilitate development of Darwin-based MEP models, but will also contribute significantly to our theoretical understanding of how microbial communities organize to facilitate the dissipation of available free energy as well as to advance consumer-resource theory for microbial systems that are the foundation of all ecosystems.

por.por_cntn:
Similar to food webs we are all familiar with, such as plants, rabbits and foxes, microbes form complex food webs as well, where bacteria, that breakdown and eat dead organic matter, are preyed upon by small protists, which in tern are consumed by larger single cell organisms, such as ciliates, and so on. Initial modeling work conducted by the principal investigators showed that how microbial food webs are organized, that is, who eats whom, greatly impacts how the food webs operate as a system and how effectively they utilize available resources. To test the model derived hypothesis, the principal investigators conducted a unique experiment to examine if food webs are highly interconnected, where everything eats everything else, or weakly connected, where microbes specialize in what, or whom, they eat. The experiment consisted of laboratory bioreactors that were fed a media with defined chemical compounds consisting of glucose, xylose, acetate, ethanol and methanol. Six bioreactors where run in parallel where one of the 5 compounds was labeled with a stable isotope of carbon (13C), which can be detected in bacteria and protists, but otherwise does alter the behavior or growth characteristics. As a microbe eats a compound, or another microbe, that contains 13C, the organism becomes “heavy” with the 13C isotope, including C in its DNA and RNA. The technique is called Stable Isotope Probing (SIP). The heavy RNA, which the investigators targeted, can be separated from the unlabeled, “light”, RNA using ultracentrifugation, and both pools of RNA (light and heavy) can be sequenced separately, thereby identifying the organisms that eat light (unlabeled) or heavy food items. By using this approach, the investigators were able to examine if microbial food webs are dominated by generalists (eating many different compounds or organisms) or specialists (eating only a single food source or prey).

After RNA sequencing of more than 2300 samples from the experiment, the investigators were able to show that the 13C-labeled compounds were consumed and that the 13C label was incorporated into bacteria and protist RNA under conditions of rapid growth (batch conditions) and steady-state growth (conducted in a chemostat). The results showed that some bacteria did specialize in consuming a single compound from the 5 that were present, while other bacteria were more generalists, consuming 2, 3 or 4 of the labeled compounds. On average, the bacteria exhibited more generalist behavior, taking up on average 3 substrates under steady growth, and 4 under rapid growth. While results are still preliminary for protists that eat bacteria, they showed to be slight specialists under steady growth, taking up bacteria that had consumed 2 substrates, but more generalists under rapid growth, consuming bacteria that had consumed closer to 5 substrates. Some of the experimental results agreed with the model developed for the project, while others disagree. The principal investigators are refining their understanding of microbial foods webs based on their experiment and are revising their model accordingly.

During the course of the project, three postdoctoral investigators were trained in Stable Isotope Probing techniques, operation of laboratory bioreactors, as well as in modeling microbial food webs using theories from thermodynamics. In addition, the project educationally supported 9 undergraduates and leveraged the support from two other institutions (the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and the Joint Genome Institute). To date, the project has produced 4 publications, and results from the project have been presented at numerous national and international conferences, as well as at many departmental seminars. Results from the project have advanced our understanding on the structure of microbial food webs and our ability to predictively model their growth and the food web structures they form.
